stargazer.requirement: Play a game where you take turns give and following commands. Search for “Simon Says” or the “If/Then/Else Game
Share the "algorithm" (in words or pictures) for brushing your teeth, washing your hands, or another activity that you perform daily, following a specific sequence.

junior.requirement: Create a bracelet or keychain with your name written in colored beads, coded using the ASCII Binary Alphabet.

Complete an un-plugged activity where you “program” other Navigators using “commands”. Examples include: a) Algorithm Pictionary using index cards with simple pictures (square, smiley face, tent, sailboat, etc.) in a bag to be drawn by players to provide precise instructions to others. The goal is to have the 2 pictures match as closely as possible. b) Graph Programming. c) Search for "Move it, ove it!"
Play a board game with your chapter or family that teaches programming (such as Qwirkle, Robot Turtles, Code Master, Code Monkey Island, etc).
Coplete a visual or performing art project taht explores loops and repeated steps. Search for Loopy Dance Party and Functional Suncatchers. Follow a pattern to knit a potholder or simple hat.
Use Legos or other building blocks to explore coding. Search for Code a Lego Maze, Complete a Bits & Bricks activity. Write a message with bricks using the ASCII Binary Alphabet.

senior.requirement: Build a simple robot (examples: emotion machine, wobblebot, wigglebot) ( if the robot can successfully navigate a maze; if the robot can demonstrate decision making)
Complete an online tutorial or course that uses Javscript. Search for "Code the News"
Search for and complete a unit of Creative Computing.
Create and publish a website for your chapter using Mozilla Thimble or a related platform.

Research five careers that require knowledge in programming. Pick one and find out the education, training, and experience required by interviewing someone in this field. Is this a career that you would want to pursue? Why or why not?
Use a program like Artist or Scratch to create a computer animation lasting at least 30 seconds.
Create a video game using Scratch, Python, C/C++ or language of your choice.
Complete a coding class, a high school level coding class, or a college level coding class.
Write, debug, and demonstrate a mobile phone application that solves a problem for someone in your community.
Add an activity your chapter or a member of your chapter designed. Your leaders will need to approve the activity and can award up to 2 stars based on difficulty..

stargazer.requirement: Identify the different parts of a tent (ground cloth, fly, tent, stakes, etc.). Help raise and take down a tent. Be safe around them (no running by because of hidden trip hazards. Learn what activities can damage them.)
Know what to do if you get lost while camping.

junior.requirement: Pitch and take downa  tent without adult assistance.
Make a part in a skit, song or activity around the campfire.
Make a packing list for a 2-night camping trip.

Build & light a campfire appropriate for the location where you are camping. Identify the 3 different types of fuel used for a campfire.Have all necessary supplies for extinguishing the fire at the campfire site before lighting the first match (incl. shovel, water bucket).
Make sure that you check the fire danger level every time you go camping.
Sleep outdoors in a tent for one night.
Name the fabrics you would want your clothing to be for a summer and winter trip. How many layers of each would you need?
Study the occurrence of forest fires in your state or a nearby state. Learn about fire risk levels. If possible attend a presentation by a park ranger or similar.
Name 5 things you can do to lighten your gear for a backpacking trip (example - cut the handle off your toothbrush or use a lighter kids' toothbrush).

What would your packing list be for a lightweight hiking trip? BONUS - look up the gear specifications and get the weight of each item or weigh any items you already own. Can you have a pack under 35 lbs. with food and fuel for 5 days?

senior.requirement: What plant and animal hazards exist where you will be camping? How do you avoid or prevent problems? What do you do if exposure to the danger occurs?

Discuss the features of land that make a good and bad campsite. Discuss what is needed nearby to camp (do you need a water source or are you bringing water in on your own). Where will the restroom be used? How does the need for camp change if you are car camping/ bike packing/car camping/boat camping? Where will you cook and what is your fuel source. Do you need to worry about shelter for lighting/tornadoes/flash flooding/ high tide/or other dangers local to you?

Sleep in a tent for 10 nights: they do not have to be consecutive nights. (you may count any camping you have done since you turned 4 years old if you are a Stargazer or Junior, from age 11 on if you are a Senior. (Two Stars: Sleep 10 additional nights in a tent).
Make a fire without using a match. Make sure you leave the area with no sign that there was a fire there.(Two Stars: if you successfully use 2 different methods).
Add an activity your chapter or a member of your chapter designed. Your leaders will need to approve the activity and can award up to 2 stars based on difficulty.
